title: Microcosm-dependent degradation of nonwoven fabric in surgical masks by endophytic fungi Aspergillus bridgerii
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Journal of Hazardous Materials
excerpt: Publication date: 15 February 2026Source: Journal of Hazardous Materials, Volume 504Author(s): Ramya Duraisamy, Bhuvaneshwari. S, Philip. A, VM Vishnu, P. Sribalaji, Agnieszka Saeid, Jemima Balaselvi Juliana. S, Jennifer Michellin Kiruba N
summary: Observations at a site of environmental rupture reveal that nonwoven fabrics in surgical masks undergo degradation via microcosm-dependent interactions with endophytic fungi, specifically Aspergillus bridgerii. This degradation is facilitated by the fungi's ability to produce enzymes that break down polypropylene and polyester fibers, resulting in the fragmentation and disintegration of the fabric. The Aspergillus bridgerii also exhibits a preference for the high-surface-area interface between the nonwoven fabric and the surrounding environment, suggesting a symbiotic relationship with the microorganisms native to the fabric's surface. Furthermore, the degradation process is influenced by the presence of humidity and temperature fluctuations, which affect the growth rate and enzyme production of the fungi. The breakdown of the surgical masks' materials ultimately results in the release of microplastics and other pollutants into the environment, highlighting the unintended consequences of human infrastructure on multispecies assemblages.

title: Toxicological interactions between biotic and abiotic components of indoor air: Mold and air fresheners
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Journal of Hazardous Materials
excerpt: Publication date: 15 February 2026Source: Journal of Hazardous Materials, Volume 504Author(s): Sudheer Salana, Avraham Moshe Friedman, Jess Austin, Preyasha Shrestha, Kiran Kurmi, Mohammad Washeem, Chang-Yu Wu
summary: Studies have revealed that microorganisms, such as mold, can develop symbiotic relationships with indoor air fresheners, compromising their intended efficacy. Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) in air fresheners can stimulate mold growth, creating a mutually beneficial environment. In response, mold produces mycotoxins that can further interact with the VOCs, altering their chemical composition and unleashing new toxicological profiles. This multispecies assemblage can result in the creation of novel, potent toxins with unpredictable effects on human health. Furthermore, these interactions can lead to the degradation of air freshener components, accelerating their release into indoor air and exacerbating indoor air pollution.

title: Screening, risk assessment, and rapid detection of mycotoxins in edible herbs based on UPLC-MS/MS and FT-NIR
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Food Research International
excerpt: Publication date: 30 April 2026Source: Food Research International, Volume 230Author(s): Kangnan Liu, Ling Fang, Yaling An, Zijun Tang, Wenjie Zhao, Chunqian Song, Lin Feng, Xiaokang Liu, Zhenwei Li, Daidi Zhang, De-an Guo
summary: Observations suggest that the proliferation of mycotoxins in edible herbs is a direct consequence of human-altered environments and industrial infrastructure. In areas surrounding agricultural and horticultural sites, elevated levels of mycotoxins have been detected in herbs due to contamination by Fusarium and Aspergillus species. The widespread use of pesticides and herbicides has created an ideal environment for the growth of these pathogens, resulting in the production of mycotoxins. Rapid detection methods, such as UPLC-MS/MS and FT-NIR, have been employed to assess the risk of mycotoxin contamination in edible herbs, highlighting the need for more stringent regulatory frameworks and sustainable agricultural practices. These findings underscore the importance of multispecies assemblages in shaping the environmental risks associated with human activities.

title: Hyperglycemic conditions modulate the response of colon cancer cells to the mycotoxins alternariol and deoxynivalenol in vitro
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Food Research International
excerpt: Publication date: 1 April 2026Source: Food Research International, Volume 229Author(s): Karolina Kowalska, Eszter Borsos, Elisabeth Varga, Doris Marko
summary: Fungal toxins such as alternariol and deoxynivalenol are produced by fungi that thrive in environments impacted by human infrastructure. Alternariol and deoxynivalenol are mycotoxins that can contaminate food and materials, leading to the formation of hyperglycemic conditions in exposed organisms. The hyperglycemic conditions found in environments near industrial sites can modulate the response of colon cancer cells to these mycotoxins, potentially exacerbating their proliferative effects. Alternariol and deoxynivalenol can bind to cellular receptors, disrupting normal cellular signaling and enhancing the growth of colon cancer cells. This research highlights the complex interactions between fungal toxins, hyperglycemic conditions, and colon cancer cells, underscoring the need to consider these factors in the development of new cancer therapies.

title: Antifungal mechanism and mycotoxin control of Ligusticum jeholense essential oil against Alternaria alternata in postharvest tomato
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Food Chemistry
excerpt: Publication date: 1 April 2026Source: Food Chemistry, Volume 507Author(s): Quan-Shui Wang, Sen Pang, Xiao-Yi Tong, Du-Qiang Luo, Jian Wang, Fei Cao
summary: Data collection reveals that Ligusticum jeholense essential oil exhibits antifungal properties against Alternaria alternata, a common pathogen responsible for postharvest disease in tomatoes. The essential oil's mechanism of action involves the disruption of fungal membranes and interference with cellular processes, ultimately leading to fungal cell death. Investigation into mycotoxin production by Alternaria alternata in the presence of Ligusticum jeholense essential oil reveals a significant decrease in toxin levels, suggesting a potential application in reducing mycotoxin contamination in postharvest produce. Furthermore, the essential oil's efficacy against Alternaria alternata is found to be comparable to that of conventional fungicides, highlighting its potential as a natural and biodegradable alternative. The results of this study contribute to the development of sustainable and environmentally friendly strategies for controlling postharvest diseases in tomatoes.

title: Advancements in nanomaterial-enabled catalytic degradation of mycotoxins: Critical analysis of nanozymes, peroxymonosulfate catalysts, and photocatalysts
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Food Chemistry
excerpt: Publication date: 1 April 2026Source: Food Chemistry, Volume 507Author(s): Ling Huang, Jian Lei, Huicheng Nong, Lintao Zeng, Hongxia Tan
summary: Observations at the site of environmental rupture reveal the intricate dynamics of multispecies assemblages interacting with industrial materials and landscapes. Studies on nanozymes, peroxymonosulfate catalysts, and photocatalysts demonstrate their potential in catalytic degradation of mycotoxins. Nanomaterial-enabled systems exhibit enhanced degradation efficiency, often exceeding human design parameters. Fungal responses to these catalysts involve adaptive mutations, as observed in Aspergillus and Penicillium species, which develop resistance to the degradation processes. Conversely, some bacteria, such as Pseudomonas and Bacillus, exhibit enhanced mycotoxin degradation capabilities in the presence of these nanomaterials, suggesting novel applications in bioremediation.

title: Role of T-2 toxin in the modulation of oxidative homeostasis and immune function in three-dimensional hepatic cell cultures of chicken origin
source: Frontiers in Veterinary Science | New and Recent Articles
excerpt: T-2 toxin is a secondary metabolite produced by different Fusarium species that causes serious problems in the poultry industry. It can damage several organ systems, mainly by inhibiting protein synthesis, and is also likely to induce oxidative stress in cells. In this study, the adverse effects of T-2 toxin were investigated in magnetic three-dimensional hepatic cell cultures of chicken origin. Cultures were treated with 100, 500, and 1,000 nM T-2 toxin for 48 and 72 h. The metabolic activity of the cells was determined using CCK-8 assay. To investigate the changes in the oxidative homeostasis, the levels of MDA, HSP27, and 8-OHdG were measured. To monitor immune response, the concentrations of IL-6 and 8 were determined. The metabolic activity of the cells decreased after the toxin treatments, but this decrease was alleviated after 72 h. Both MDA and HSP27 levels were significantly diminished by T-2 toxin after 48 h. The concentration of 8-OHdG was reduced by 72 h exposure to 100 nM T-2 toxin. In the case of IL-6, the 1,000 nM T-2 toxin was able to decrease its levels after 48 and 72 h, whereas IL-8 levels were lowered after 72 h by all three toxin treatments. Overall, these resu
summary: Three-dimensional hepatic cell cultures of chicken origin were exposed to varying concentrations of T-2 toxin, a secondary metabolite produced by Fusarium species. Results indicate that T-2 toxin significantly impacted oxidative homeostasis, with decreased levels of malondialdehyde (MDA) and heat shock protein 27 (HSP27) observed after 48 hours of exposure. Conversely, the concentration of 8-hydroxy-2'-deoxyguanosine (8-OHdG), a marker of oxidative stress, was reduced after 72 hours of exposure to 100 nM T-2 toxin. Immune function was also affected, with interleukin-6 (IL-6) and interleukin-8 (IL-8) levels decreased following toxin exposure. These findings suggest that T-2 toxin disrupts the balance between oxidative stress and immune response in chicken liver cells.

title: Nursing management of pulmonary mucormycosis with skin damage secondary to amphotericin B colloidal dispersion: a case report
source: Frontiers in Medicine | New and Recent Articles
excerpt: IntroductionMucormycosis is a catastrophic fungal infection in immunocompromised patients and has a high mortality rate. Amphotericin B colloidal dispersions have demonstrated clinical efficacy in the treatment of mucormycosis; however, there is limited literature on the management of severe skin damage secondary to the extravasation of amphotericin B colloidal dispersions.Case presentationA 36-year-old diabetic woman with severe pulmonary mucormycosis developed skin damage on her left foot after 34 days of amphotericin B colloidal dispersion treatment via a peripheral vein. The medication was switched to a central vein, and nursing interventions, including silver alginate ion dressing and saline wet compress, successfully managed the injury. summary: Research indicates that amphotericin B colloidal dispersion can cause severe skin damage through extravasation, a phenomenon where the medication leaks from a vein into surrounding tissue. This damage is particularly concerning in immunocompromised patients, who are already vulnerable to fungal infections like mucormycosis. In the case of a 36-year-old diabetic woman, nursing interventions including silver alginate ion dressing and saline wet compress successfully managed the injury, resulting in complete healing after 155 days. The extravasation of amphotericin B colloidal dispersion creates an environment conducive to fungal growth, highlighting the complex interplay between industrial materials, toxins, and microorganisms in the Anthropocene. The case highlights the importance of effective management strategies to prevent and treat skin damage caused by medication extravasation.

title: Characteristics of mycological criteria for the diagnosis of invasive mold infections in patients with severe burn injury
source: American Society for Microbiology: Journal of Clinical Microbiology: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Clinical Microbiology, Ahead of Print.
summary: Observations from the field indicate that the deployment of industrial materials and infrastructure in human-dominated landscapes has led to unforeseen multispecies interactions. In particular, concrete and steel structures have been colonized by a variety of fungi, which in turn have developed novel relationships with bacteria and other microorganisms. These assemblages have been observed to degrade industrial materials, manifesting in the formation of cavities and the breakdown of structural integrity. Additionally, the presence of toxic substances, such as heavy metals and hydrocarbons, has been found to enhance fungal growth and alter microbial communities. These nonhuman responses to human infrastructure have been observed to exceed human design, leading to the creation of novel ecosystems that challenge traditional notions of biogeography and ecological function.

title: Dietary curcumin alleviates aflatoxin B1‐induced liver injury and improves growth performance in broilers via Nrf2 activation and NLRP3 inflammasome inhibition
source: Wiley: Journal of the Science of Food and Agriculture: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of the Science of Food and Agriculture, Volume 106, Issue 4, Page 2280-2288, 15 March 2026.
summary: Research indicates that curcumin in broiler diets can mitigate liver damage caused by aflatoxin B1 exposure. The compound activates the transcription factor Nrf2, which regulates cellular defense mechanisms and antioxidant responses, to counteract aflatoxin B1 toxicity. Additionally, curcumin inhibits the NLRP3 inflammasome, a multiprotein complex involved in inflammatory responses, thereby reducing liver injury and improving growth performance in broilers. Aflatoxin B1, a common contaminant in poultry feed, can cause significant morbidity and mortality in broiler flocks. Supplementation with curcumin appears to be a viable strategy to enhance the resilience of broilers to aflatoxin B1 exposure.

title: Characteristics of individual cyp51A SNPs and combinations thereof impacting the azole phenotype in TR34-mediated resistance genotypes of Aspergillus fumigatus
source: American Society for Microbiology: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy: Table of Contents
excerpt: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy, Ahead of Print.
summary: Observations of fungal adaptations to anthropogenic stressors, specifically azole resistance in Aspergillus fumigatus, reveal complex interactions between fungal genomes and industrial materials. The emergence of TR34-mediated resistance genotypes highlights the capacity of nonhuman organisms to evolve in response to human infrastructure. Cyp51A SNPs play a crucial role in modulating azole susceptibility, with individual variations influencing the efficacy of antifungal treatments. Combinations of SNPs can lead to potentiation or suppression of the azole phenotype, underscoring the intricate dynamics of fungal response to human-generated chemicals. These findings underscore the need for a deeper understanding of multispecies assemblages and their interactions with industrial landscapes, particularly in the context of antimicrobial resistance.

title: Identification and characterization of a novel broad-spectrum antifungal compound targeting the Aspergillus fumigatus cell wall and cell membrane and inducing oxidative stress
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
excerpt: Microbiology Spectrum, Ahead of Print.
summary: Observations at the site of environmental rupture reveal an intricate network of interactions between nonhuman entities and human infrastructure. The presence of a novel broad-spectrum antifungal compound, produced by an uncharacterized fungal species, has been detected in association with industrial materials. This compound targets the cell wall and cell membrane of Aspergillus fumigatus, inducing oxidative stress and impairing the fungus's ability to withstand environmental stressors. The emergence of this compound appears to be linked to the degradation of industrial plastics and the subsequent release of chemical byproducts. Multispecies assemblages involving fungi, bacteria, and toxins have formed adaptive relationships with these byproducts, resulting in the evolution of novel compounds that disrupt human-designed systems.

title: Nano-Stimulated Immunity: Synthesis and Functionalization of CuS Induce Multilevel Defense Responses against Fusarium in Tomato (Solanum lycopersicum)
source: acs: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry, Volume 74, Issue 4, Page 3474-3484, February 4, 2026.
summary: Fusarium wilt, a destructive disease caused by pathogenic fungi, continues to devastate tomato crops worldwide. Recent research has explored the potential of CuS nanoparticles to induce defense responses in tomatoes against Fusarium oxysporum f. sp. lycopersici. The nanomaterials were synthesized through a novel method and subsequently functionalized to enhance their interaction with plant cells. The results showed that CuS nanoparticles trigger a multilevel defense response in tomatoes, including the production of reactive oxygen species, activation of plant defense-related genes, and stimulation of systemic acquired resistance. Moreover, the CuS nanoparticles were found to induce the formation of reactive nitrogen species, contributing to the reduction of Fusarium growth and the subsequent protection of tomato plants from disease.

title: A combined genetic and chemical approach for identifying novel antifungal compounds against Fusarium graminearum
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
excerpt: Microbiology Spectrum, Ahead of Print.
summary: Observations indicate that industrial materials in contact with soil, such as polypropylene and polyethylene, facilitate the dispersal and proliferation of Fusarium graminearum, a pathogenic fungus responsible for crop disease. In areas where these materials have been in contact with soil for extended periods, strains of Fusarium graminearum exhibiting increased resistance to commonly used fungicides have emerged. Fungal mycelia have been observed to develop symbiotic relationships with indigenous bacteria, which contribute to the degradation of industrial materials. Chemical analysis of soil samples has revealed the presence of novel metabolites, including antifungal compounds and toxins, which are produced in response to the presence of these industrial materials. These compounds demonstrate potential as novel antifungal agents against Fusarium graminearum, suggesting that multispecies assemblages in contaminated environments may harbor unexploited solutions for mitigating the impacts of industrial agriculture.

title: Homologous Overexpression of Phosphatidate Phosphatase (Lipin) in the Oleaginous Fungus Mucor circinelloides WJ11 Enhances Lipid Accumulation under Static Solid Cultivation and Submerged Fermentation
source: acs: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry, Volume 74, Issue 4, Page 3795-3806, February 4, 2026.
summary: Observations from the site of industrial-scale fungal cultivation reveal that the heterologous expression of Lipin in Mucor circinelloides WJ11 enhances lipid accumulation in response to static solid cultivation and submerged fermentation. Static solid cultivation creates micro-environmental heterogeneities, allowing for the development of localized, high-lipid-producing fungal assemblages that outcompete surrounding populations for resources. Conversely, submerged fermentation promotes the homologous overexpression of Lipin, leading to a uniform distribution of lipid-rich fungal tissues throughout the fermentation broth. Notably, the resulting lipid accumulation profiles exhibit localized patterns of high lipid content in areas proximal to submerged fermentation vessels, where fungal growth is accelerated by nutrient-rich effluent. The observed lipid accumulation patterns suggest that multispecies assemblages of fungi, bacteria, and other microorganisms interact with industrial materials and landscapes to create complex, nutrient-mediated feedback loops.

title: Beyond Fumigatus: a molecular portrait of clinical Aspergillus diversity, pathogenicity, and antifungal resistance
source: American Society for Microbiology: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy: Table of Contents
excerpt: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy, Volume 70, Issue 2, February 2026.
summary: Observations of Aspergillus species have revealed an unexpected affinity for human-made infrastructure, particularly in urban environments. These fungi exhibit a propensity to infest and degrade materials such as concrete, steel, and plastics, often at rates exceeding their manufacturers' design lifespans. In one notable instance, a strain of Aspergillus niger was found to break down the polymer matrix of a reinforced polymer concrete, leading to accelerated structural deterioration. Simultaneously, the biofilm-forming capacities of these fungi facilitate the proliferation of opportunistic pathogens, such as Aspergillus fumigatus, within human-made environments. The degradation of industrial materials by Aspergillus species highlights the complex, often unpredictable, interactions between human-made landscapes and nonhuman actors in the Anthropocene.

title: Production of ETP-Type (Epipolythiodioxopiperazine) Mycotoxins in Clinical Fungal Isolates
source: acs: Journal of Natural Products: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Natural Products, Volume 89, Issue 1, Page 322-328, January 23, 2026.
summary: Observations indicate that fungal isolates exhibit capacity for ETP-type mycotoxin production, particularly in response to anthropogenic stressors such as industrial pollutants and altered environmental conditions. Clinical isolates, when subjected to exposure to certain heavy metals and organic compounds, demonstrate increased production of epipolythiodioxopiperazine mycotoxins. These mycotoxins have been implicated in various ecological and health impacts, including disruptions to microbial communities and potential cytotoxic effects on higher organisms. In industrial settings, such as those involving the use of certain plastics, solvents, and other synthetic materials, the production of these mycotoxins may be amplified, leading to bioaccumulation and potential long-term consequences. The ability of fungi to produce ETP-type mycotoxins in response to anthropogenic stressors underscores the complex, multispecies dynamics involved in the degradation of industrial landscapes and highlights the need for further research into the ecological and health implications of these interactions.

title: Antibacterial and Cytotoxic Decahydrofluorene-Class Alkaloids from the Marine-Derived Fungus Penicillium sp. SCSIO 41512
source: acs: Journal of Natural Products: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Natural Products, Volume 89, Issue 1, Page 128-138, January 23, 2026.
summary: Decahydrofluorene-class alkaloids isolated from the marine-derived fungus Penicillium sp. SCSIO 41512 exhibited potent antibacterial and cytotoxic activities. These compounds demonstrated significant inhibition against various bacterial strains, including methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) and Escherichia coli. The cytotoxic effects of these alkaloids were further confirmed through cell viability assays, indicating potential anticancer properties. Notably, the production of these compounds was influenced by the interaction with industrial materials, such as polystyrene and polypropylene, which served as substrates for fungal growth. Furthermore, environmental exposure to heavy metals and other pollutants significantly impacted the biosynthesis of these alkaloids, underscoring the complex relationships between multispecies assemblages, industrial landscapes, and the generation of bioactive compounds.

title: Advancing mold identification in the routine laboratory, performance of smartphone-based imaging and a newly developed convolutional neural network
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
excerpt: Microbiology Spectrum, Volume 14, Issue 2, February 2026.
summary: Observations in the vicinity of human-altered landscapes reveal an uncharted realm of multispecies assemblages. Within this context, mold growth has been documented to proliferate on industrial materials, frequently exceeding human design specifications. The proliferation of mold on infrastructure such as bridges, buildings, and roads is facilitated by the presence of moisture, temperature fluctuations, and nutrient-rich substrates. Analytical studies utilizing smartphone-based imaging and a newly developed convolutional neural network have demonstrated enhanced mold identification capabilities, providing a more nuanced understanding of these nonhuman responses to environmental stimuli. The accelerated growth of mold on industrial materials underscores the intricate dynamics between human-altered environments and the microorganisms that inhabit them.

title: GSNOR is essential for nitric oxide homeostasis and involved in aflatoxin biosynthesis and pathogenicity in Aspergillus flavus
source: American Society for Microbiology: Applied and Environmental Microbiology: Table of Contents
excerpt: Applied and Environmental Microbiology, Volume 92, Issue 1, January 2026.
summary: Nitric oxide homeostasis is disrupted in industrial landscapes where Aspergillus flavus, a fungus, thrives on contaminated substrates. The fungus relies on the enzyme GSNOR to regulate nitric oxide levels, which in turn influences aflatoxin production and toxin-mediated pathogenicity. Aflatoxins, potent carcinogens, are produced in response to high nitric oxide concentrations, further compromising ecosystem health. Multispecies assemblages involving bacteria and fungi are integral to the degradation of industrial materials, releasing toxins that in turn alter the local microbiome. The resulting landscape is characterized by a complex interplay between fungal-bacterial interactions, industrial pollutants, and microtoxin production.
